resources.title: Treatment of the Occult Tethered Spinal Cord for Neuropathic Bladder: Results of Sectioning the Filum Terminale
resources.summary:
Study of 36 patients with severe urinary and/or fecal dysfunction, but with no indication of tethered cord on imaging.

After sectioning of filum terminale, incontinence was resolved in 42% of patients. Urodynamics improved in 72%, bowel symptoms improved in 88%.

resources.title: Clinical evidence for cervical myelopathy due to Chiari malformation and spinal stenosis in a non-randomized group of patients with the diagnosis of fibromyalgia
resources.summary:
270 non-randomized patients with a diagnosis of Fibromayalgia and no previous diagnosis of neurological issues were given a neurological assessment for cervical myelopathy and then given imaging. 46% of patients showed cervical stenosis of 10 mm or less.

Study authors recommended further neurological evaluation of patients with Fibromayalgia for neurological issues.

resources.title: Connective tissue, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome(s), and head and cervical pain
resources.summary:
This paper covers the results of a large cohort study of over 2,000 patients with hypermobile connective tissue disorders and Chiari malformation (>5 mm), comparing the different cohorts with each other and healthy controls.

The paper asserts an association between connective tissue disorders and Chiari Malformation (2 mesodermal disorders). Patients with both connective tissue disorders and Chiari Malformation have a unique set of symptoms including a greater incidence of occipitoatlantoaxial hypermobility, and this tissue laxity can result in the unique problem of functional cranial settling, which is outlined in this paper, as well as other issues such as caudal displacement of the cerebellar tonsils, retro-odontoid pannus formation, and symptoms referable to basilar impression.

resources.title: Cervical medullary syndrome secondary to craniocervical instability and ventral brainstem compression in hereditary hypermobility connective tissue disorders: 5-year follow-up after craniocervical reduction, fusion, and stabilization
resources.summary:
This paper is the first 5-year retrospective study of its kind. It is a case series of 22 patients with hypermobile CTDs and complex Chiari patient's (with both Chiari and CCI, basilar invagination, etc.) surgery outcomes 5 years after fusion surgeries. The results were highly positive with no morbidity, few complications (most of the complications involving bone graft harvesting), and patient satisfaction, with 14/20 subjects greatly improving quality of life and functional capacity.

Henderson also explains the various neurological measurements involved in assessing for CCI (with pictures) and describes his surgical technique (also with diagrams). A helpful diagram and list of the top symptoms experience pre- and post-op by patients is also included.

resources.title: Diagnosis of Atlantoaxial Instability Requires Clinical Suspicion to Drive the Radiological Investigation
resources.summary:
This article describes Atlanto-Axial Instability (AAI), or hypermobility of the C1-2 segment:

- Its diagnosis (with CT, DMX/X-ray, and MRI)
- The symptoms it causes
- Criteria for surgery
- The patient populations it commonly appears in. 

The author emphasizes that non-traumatic AAI often requires dynamic imaging for proper diagnosis and treatment.

resources.title: Signs of Intracranial Hypertension, Hypermobility, and Craniocervical Obstructions in Patients With Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
resources.summary:
In this retrospective, cross-sectional study, the study authors sought to assess whether hypermobility and neurological/neurosurgical issues could be responsible for at least some explanation of the symptoms of severe Myalgic Encaphalomyelitis (ME) (Canada Consensus Criteria). 

229 patients (190 women and 39 men) were assessed for hypermobility (Beighton Score), intracranial hypertension (quotient of the optic nerve sheet diameter (ONSD)/eyeball transverse diameter on both sides), cerebellar tonsil position (McRae's line), craniocervical obstructions, allodynia (quantitative sensory testing (QST)).

The study found a significantly higher percentage of patients in the severe ME population than the general population, with fully half or more of the patients exhibiting these pathologies.

resources.title: Autoantibodies to beta-adrenergic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors in Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME) patients – A validation study in plasma and cerebrospinal fluid from two Swedish cohorts
resources.summary:
If you have these antibodies, the acetylcholine receptors on your cells may be damaged, meaning you need, in essence, more acetylcholine than usual to function properly. 

Mestinon blocks acetylcholinesterase, an enzyme that breaks down acetylcholine, thereby increasing acetylcholine. 

Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter of the vagus nerve. It also regulates mast cell degranulation, and so may pay a role in MCAS.

resources.title: Biomechanics of the cervical spine. I: Normal kinematics
resources.summary:
In the first of four installments of what are essentially anatomy primers, the article authors detail the current knowledge of the cervical spine, and it's mechanics of the vertebra and soft tissues under normal conditions and conditions that can cause injury. The authors describe in detail the basic anatomy of the cervical spine and how it affects joint movement and summarize collated research articles on range of motion of each of the joints of the cervical spine, the order of movement of the vertebra in flexion and extension, and also the centers of rotation, mechanics, and biological basis.

The link is to an abstract only, and readers must view the attached PDF for the full text.

resources.title: Altered Structural Brain Networks Related to Adrenergic/Muscarinic Receptor Autoantibodies in Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
resources.summary:
If you have these antibodies, the acetylcholine receptors on your cells may be damaged, meaning you need, in essence, more acetylcholine than usual to function properly. 

Mestinon blocks acetylcholinesterase, an enzyme that breaks down acetylcholine, thereby increasing acetylcholine. 

Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter of the vagus nerve. It also regulates mast cell degranulation, and so may pay a role in MCAS.

resources.title: Cerebral Blood Flow Is Reduced in ME/CFS During Head-Up Tilt Testing Even in the Absence of Hypotension or Tachycardia: A Quantitative, Controlled Study Using Doppler Echography
resources.summary: Doppler flow imaging was used to measure cerebral blood flow (CBF) in 429 ME/CFS patients and 44 healthy controls during a head-up tilt test. CBF was reduced 26% in ME/CFS patients vs. 7% in controls. CBF reduction was > 2 standard deviations in 90% of ME/CFS patients vs 13% of controls.

resources.title: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome: A Primer for the Gastroenterologist
resources.summary: "Gastroenterologists who become aware of this syndrome can dramatically improve the quality of life for their patients who previously have been labeled with a functional gastrointestinal disorder."

resources.title: Neurological and spinal manifestations of the Ehlers–Danlos syndromes
resources.summary:
Connective tissue disorders cause downstream issues including:

- Migraine
- Idiopathic intracranial hypo/hypertension
- Chiari malformation
- Atlantoaxial instability
- Craniocervical instability
- Tethered cord syndrome

resources.title: Nontraumatic Atlanto-occipital and Atlantoaxial Rotatory Subluxation: Case Report
resources.summary: Interesting case study of a 13 year-old girl who developed CCI/AAI following a neck infection.

resources.title: Improvement of severe ME/CFS symptoms following surgical treatment of cervical spinal stenosis
resources.summary:
Case study of 3 moderate/severe ME/CFS patients who were diagnosed with cervical stenosis following a cervical MRI. 
Measures of neurological function improved significantly after treatment.

resources.title: Incidence of Extrinsic Compression of the Internal Jugular Vein in Unselected Patients Undergoing CT Angiography
resources.summary:
Study of 108 consecutive patients already having a (supine) CT angiogram for reasons other than vascular issues (so although these are not healthy controls, there's no strong reason to believe their symptoms are because of stenosis).

Interestingly, 67.6% of people had some narrowing of one or other jugular.

Collateral veins can form around the main veins when flow is blocked. But the study shows a complex picture where although collateral veins are far more common in people with stenosis of the main vein, they can also be present without; and severe stenosis can exist without the formation of collateral vessels.

As with so many  comorbidities we've found in our cohort of people with ME, identification of pathologies requires specialist knowledge,  sophisticated reading of imagery, and many signs can be incidental in patients without symptoms.

resources.title: A case-control study of cerebellar tonsillar ectopia (Chiari) andhead/neck trauma (whiplash)
resources.summary:
In this case-control study, the authors examined the frequency of cerebellar tonsillar ectopia (CTE) in 1,200 MRIs (half upright, half supine) of patients with neck pain, divided into a population of patients who had had a traumatic whiplash injury (600), and a population who had not (600). 

Notably, CTE was found 2.5-times more often in the upright trauma vs the recumbent trauma group and 4-times more often than in either of the non-trauma groups.  The authors conclude that, while more research is needed since this is the first study of its kind, clinicians may want to evaluate their patients for CTE if they have neck pain, a history of a whiplash injury, and other common signs such as bilateral sensory or motor deficits in the upper extremities.

The authors also discussed other effects of whiplash injuries such as dural leaks (CSF leaks).

resources.title: Atlanto-axial rotary instability (Fielding type 1): characteristic clinical and radiological findings, and treatment outcomes following alignment, fusion, and stabilization
resources.summary:
Great info on rotary AAI, why it is failed to be diagnosed, and why surgery is harder in CTD patients.

Discusses "occult"  hypermobility- where artifacts are not not visible on traditional scans.

"The alar ligament consists chiefly of inelastic collagen fibers, and can be irreversibly stretched after trauma, potentially leading to chronic occult hypermobility of the cranio-cervical junction.“

resources.title: Meningocele Manqué Discovered During Filum Terminale Resection in Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome
resources.summary:
Case study of a patient with negative imaging, but symptoms of tethered cord. 

On laminectomy, it was discovered that abnormally-developing meningoceles had physically tethered the spinal cord.

Release of the filum terminale would have been insufficient to address symptoms- the tether was at L2-3.

Checking pre-operative imaging again, 3-dimensional reconstruction of a high-resolution MRI would have identified the problem ahead of surgery.

resources.title: Filum Section for Urinary Incontinence in Children with Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome: A Randomized, Controlled Pilot Study
resources.summary:
A study of 21 patients who were selected for sectioning of filum terminale based on urodynamics.

"After 8 years we accrued 21 patients. The bowel and bladder dysfunction score improved in the surgical and medical arms (20% and 24%) and the urodynamic score improved slightly (6% and 4%, respectively). The PEMQOL Child and Family Impact Scales improved modestly in both groups. All differences were nonsignificant. "

The study does not define occult tethered cord syndrome in the way we're used to, concerning itself only with urinary/bowel symptoms:

"OTCS, in which [bladder and bowel dysfunction] is attributed to tethering by the filum despite a normally located conus on MRI."

Whereas OTCS is defined by the NIH as a triad of symptoms: urinary/bowel, neurological, and orthopedic: https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/4018/occult-spinal-dysraphism

This study specifically excludes patients with symptoms in one leg of the triad:

"Evidence of progressive lower extremity motor/ sensory deficits was a patient exclusion criterion."

resources.title: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Review Article)
resources.summary:
This review article described the anatomy behind, types and symptoms of each time, diagnosis, key examination findings, and treatment of thoracic outlet syndrome in detail.

In summary, thoracic outlet syndrome is a well-described disorder caused by thoracic outlet compression of the brachial plexus and/or the subclavian vessels. Neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome is the most common manifestation, presenting with pain, numbness, tingling, weakness, and vasomotor changes of the upper extremity. Vascular complications of thoracic outlet syndrome are uncommon and include thromboembolic phenomena and swelling. The clinical presentation is highly variable, and no reproducible study exists to confirm the diagnosis; instead, the diagnosis is based on a physician’s judgment after a meticulous history and physical examination. Both nonsurgical and surgical treatment methods are available for thoracic outlet syndrome. Whereas nonsurgical management appears to be effective in some persons, surgical treatment has been shown to provide predictable long-term cure rates for carefully selected patients. In addition, physicians who do not regularly treat patients with thoracic outlet syndrome may not have an accurate view of this disorder, its treatment, or the possible success rate of treatment.

resources.title: Characterization of Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
resources.summary:
413 patients, selected both retrospectively and prospectively.

Abnormalities in routine labs were common and diverse but typically modest. The most useful diagnostic markers were heparin, prostaglandin D2, histamine, and chromogranin A. Flow cytometric and cytokine assessments were unhelpful.

Treatment of samples is crucial: "Also, other work has clarified the importance of continuous specimen chilling, including use of refrigerated centrifugation for plasma separation, when seeking plasma heparin levels."

The discussion section has some interesting speculation about whether some diagnoses found as comorbidities may in fact be unrecognised MCAS- for example GERD, thrombocytopenia purpura, polycythemia vera, etc.

resources.title: The 2017 international classification of the Ehlers–Danlos syndromes
resources.summary:
This article from 2017 updates the diagnostic criteria and classification criteria for Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) (a heritable connective tissue disorder) from the previous 1998 Villefranche Nosology's six sub-types. The International EDS Consortium proposes a revised EDS classification, which recognizes 13 subtypes.  and also proposes a pathogenetic scheme, that regroups EDS subtypes for which the causative proteins function within the same pathway (based on the different affected genes).

The authors include many helpful photos, diagrams, and charts.

resources.title: Magnetic resonance imaging in the prone position and the diagnosis of tethered spinal cord
resources.summary:
A small study showing that a comparison of conus position in the spinal canal between prone and supine MRI appears to be a sensitive and specific measure for tethered cord. 

Whereas 38/41 patients with tethered cord had diminished ventral motion, 30/30 controls had > 10% canal width motion.

resources.title: Magnetic resonance imaging in the prone position and the diagnosis of tethered spinal cord
resources.summary:
In this study, with a larger sample size than previous studies, the authors tested the hypothesis that lack of central conus motion (lack of spinal cord movement within the spinal canal) on prone MRI is a sensitive and specific test in identifying patients with occult tethered cord syndrome (OTCS) or a re-tethered cord.

Prone MRI scans from 41 patients who underwent tethered cord release surgery, grouped into 2 groups (new OTCS diagnosis and re-tethered cord) plus a third control group were examined.

Lack of conus motion was found in the OTCS groups, and the sensitivity and specifity of the test (does the test accurately show the problem without false positives?) was found to be above 97%. The authors further suggest 10% canal width motion as a threshold that can separate the tethered and the nontethered groups.

resources.title: Neurological and Spinal Manifestations of theEhlers–Danlos Syndromes
resources.summary:
On the basis of a large shared experience in the treatment of EDS, the authors were solicited to contribute a review of the neurological and spinal manifestations of EDS. In preparation for the EDS International Symposium 2016, the authors formed subcommittees to research individual topics relating to EDS and its neurological presentations, and present in this article those findings for fellow EDS medical practitioners.

The authors describe EDS (a heterogeneous group of heritable connective tissue disorders characterized by joint hypermobility, skin extensibility, and tissue fragility), then go on to describe in topic form various neurological issues that can arise from ligament and tissue laxity in the spine. 

The authors describe how stress on the nervous system (such as nerve entrapment) may alter gene and phenotype expression, as well as general nervous function. The authors also comment on the increased prevalence of migraine, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, Tarlov cysts, tethered cord syndrome, and dystonia in this patient populations, as well as Chiari Malformation Type I and craniocervical instability and basilar invagination. Ligament and tissue laxity and fragility can also cause motor delay, headache, and quadriparesis, as well as discopathy, early degenerative spondylotic disease.

The authors also comment on the painful nature of EDS and it's various associated symptoms such as weakness, myalgia, easy fatigability, limited walking, reduction of vibration sense, and impairment of mobility and daily activities.

resources.title: Venous sinus stenting for refractory benign intracranial hypertension
resources.summary: This article is a case study of a woman with refractory intracranial hypertension, who upon venography and manometry (venous imaging) was found to have partial obstruction of both transverse venous sinuses, with raised pressures proximal to the obstructions. The patient improved significantly, including her intracranial hypertension, after insertion of a stent to reduce the pressure gradient. This case study-- along with other literature supporting a relationship between intracranial pressure and venous obstruction-- indicates that venous issues should be investigated in the setting of an intracranial hypertension diagnosis.

resources.title: Effect of acetylcholine on mast cells of the dura mater
resources.summary:
In this study using rats, the authors tested the effect of various doses of acetylcholine (100, 200, and 500 mg/kg) on the mast cells of the albino rat dura mater (sheath around the spinal cord).

The authors found that acetylcholine has an activating effect on monoamine secretion, using measured differences in the accumulated or eliminated monoamines after dosing.

resources.title: Disparities in clinical and economic outcomes in children and adolescents following surgery for tethered cord syndrome in the United States
resources.summary:
In this study, the authors analyzed demographics, complications, and outcomes in children and adolescents who underwent surgery for TCS by retrospectively identifying patients in the national Kids' Inpatient Database (KID).They looked at the rate of surgery complications, surgery outcomes, comorbidities, and more, with kids grouped by age. 

A total of 7397 children and adolescents met the criteria in the 4 studied years. The mean age was 5.7 years; 55.3% of patients were younger than 5 years, 21.5% were 6–10 years, and 16.2% were 11–15 years. Most surgeries were performed in patients who were female (55.0%) and white (64.4%) and were performed at large (49.8%), teaching (94.2%), and urban (99.1%) children's (89.3%) hospitals. The trend showed an increase in prevalence from 2000 (19.9%) to 2009 (29.6%). Common comorbidities included anomalies in spinal curvature (16.7%), urinary or bladder dysfunction (14.3%), and spinal stenosis/spondylosis (1.4%). Non-routine discharges (3.3%) were significantly higher with advancing age, increasing from 2.2% in those younger than 5 years to 9.0% in those older than 15 years (p < 0.0001). There was a similar increasing trend for complications (6.8% to 13.9%, respectively, p < 0.0001) and average LOS (3.5 to 5.1 days, respectively, p < 0.0001). Hospital charges increased with age from an average of $28,521 in those younger than 5 years to $36,855 in those older than 15 years (p < 0.0001).

Older children tended to have more issues with surgery, supporting the conclusion that surgery is better done earlier in life.
###

resources.title: Ultrasonographic measurement of the optic nerve sheath diameter and its association with eyeball transverse diameter in 585 healthy volunteers
resources.summary:
In the evaluation of intracranial pressure (ICP) for the diagnosis of various disorders such as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, optic nerve sheath diameter (ONSD) is often used as an indirect marker of ICP. The authors of this study sought to clarify the unclear optimal cut-off of ONSD and the general use of ONSD in evaluating ICP.

Using ultrasonography (a non-invasive method for measuring ONSD) on 585 healthy volunteers, the authors measured ONSD, and found that of the factors studied, only eyeball transverse diameter (ETD) was independently associated with ONSD. The authors established a normative (normal) value for ONSD and ETD, and a normative value for the ONSD/ETD ratio, and further asserted that the ONSD/ETD ratio might be a more reliable marker for ICP than ONSD alone.

resources.title: The link between idiopathic intracranial hypertension, fibromyalgia, and chronic fatigue syndrome: exploration of a shared pathophysiology
resources.summary:
This article is a literature review exploring the idea that since fibromayalgia (FM) and chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) aren't well understood and their symptoms have significant overlap with idiopathic intracranial hypertention (IICH or IIH), the symptoms of FM and CFS could be caused by increased intracranial and spinal fluid pressure.

Literature reviewed discussed common symptoms for all 3 conditions and their overlap, the mechanism for nerve involvement in IICH, common symptoms associated with each nerve's involvement, the high incidence of small fiber neuropathy (SFN) in these patients, the involvement of the sympathetic nervous system, disability and quality of life among these patients, and the role of cerebral blood flow in all 3 conditions.

The authors concluded that IICH, FM, and CFS share very similar characteristics and probably are caused by the same underlying disorder, and that IICH, FM, and CFS can be considered progressive neurological disorders affecting the central and peripheral nervous systems. They point out the stigma associated with FM and CFS diagnoses and urge further investigation into treating intracranial and spinal fluid pressure.

They further assert that this hypothesis may also provide an explanation for several overlapping chronic pain conditions, including FM, CFS, temporomandibular disorders, irritable bowel syndrome, chronic tension headache, chronic migraine, severe dry eyes, and chronic nonspecific low back pain.

resources.title: Association of Chiari malformation type I and tethered cord syndrome:preliminary results of sectioning filum terminale
resources.summary:
In this retrosepctive study, the authors examined the scans of a cohort of 2,987 patients with Chiari Malformation Type I (CM-1) and 289 patients with low-lying cerebellar tonsils (LLCT), in addition to findings in 74 children and 244 adults undergoing section of the filum (SFT) (tethered cord release surgery), to determine whether there was a relationship between tethered cord and CM-1.

The authors found that there is a subset of patients who have CM-1 paired with tethered cord syndrome (TCS), different from "generic" CM-1. These patients have distinctive clinical differences: a normal foramen magnum size and the absence of a small posterior cranial fossa, as seen in "generic" CM-1. Other clinical signs that can be seen include elongation and downward displacement of the hindbrain (cerebellar tonsils), normal position of the conus medullaris, a tight filum terminale, and reduced CSF flow in the lumbar theca. 

The authors also discuss preliminary evidence that SFT can reverse moderate degrees of tonsillar ectopia and is appropriate treatment for cerebellar ptosis after Chiari surgery in this cohort.

resources.title: Utility of the clivo-axial angle in assessing brainstem deformity: pilot study and literature review
resources.summary:
This article is a literature review paired with a prospective pilot study of ten patients with ventral brainstorm deformity/compression (a kyphotic, or acute, CXA [Clivo-Axial Angle]). Correction of abnormal CXA with fusion and occipito-cervical stabilization correlated with statistically significant clinical improvement in this cohort of patients.

This study's results supported the thesis that a connection between the cervical medullary syndrome and a patient's generally disability with their CXA and assert that a reduction and fusion operation would help alleviate symptoms, after establishing that brainstem deformity has been established to cause neurological deficits.

A description of the diagnostic process, the cervicomedullary syndrome, the effects of brainstem deformity on axons and more, and the surgical procedure with diagrams is also included. This article's literature review includes a wide swath of other studies similar in nature.

resources.title: Laryngeal Manifestations of Cranial Nerve IX/X Compression at the Brainstem
resources.summary: A study focusing on laryngeal symptoms involving 49 patients with lower cranial nerve vascular compression (LCN IX/X [9 and 10]), where 24 underwent decompression surgery (retromastoid craniectomy) and 25 had conservative treatments. 10/24 surgery patients had complete or near-complete resolution of laryngeal symptoms as opposed to 2/25 conservative management patients. With 4/24 patients having major perioperative complications, the surgery is deemed to have acceptable risk.

resources.title: Grisel's syndrome: The two-hit hypothesis-A case report and literature review
resources.summary:
A case report paired with a literature review regarding Grisel's Syndrome, which is a subluxation of C1 on C2 (atlantoaxial subluxation) that didn't come from a trauma/accident (and without osteopathy).

The case study involved an otherwise healthy 11 year old boy who underwent a routine tonsillectomy, who presented day 3 post-op with increasing neck pain and was found to have a significant rotary subluxation of C1 over C2 which was treated successfully without surgery.

The authors describe Grisel's Syndrome, a primarily pediatric (under 21) syndrome occurring most often from minor surgeries such as a tonsillectomy, wherein patients primarily present with a painful tortcullis (head tilt in opposite direction of subluxation). They propose a "two-hit" hypothesis wherein patients who experience Grisel's Syndrome have an underlying laxity, with the second hit being an inflammatory process, and further discuss a diagnosis and treatment "algorithm".

resources.title: The Classic: The Cervical Syndrome.
resources.summary:
This article is a re-print of Ruth Jackson's 1949 article describing the Cervical Syndrome, a grouping of symptoms gathered by Jackson, associated with cervical nerve root irritation and broken up into vertebra levels. 

Vertebral design and function is described, as well as nerve roots and their larger system and what the nerves control at each level. Causes of nerve root irritation are also listed, chief among them subluxation or instability. Symptoms are described, as is their nature of being made worse with certain neck movements or positions. Treatment protocols are outlined for various issues causing nerve root irritation, such as bracing or injections. 

Jackson asserted the importance of cervical investigation in any patient with head, neck, chest, shoulder and arm pain, and said the usual diagnosis of neuritis, bursitis, periarthritis, myositis, fibrositis, myofascitis, pseudo-angina pectoris and migraine should not be made until cervical nerve root irritation has been ruled out entirely.

resources.title: Chronic Neck Pain: Making the Connection Between Capsular Ligament Laxity and Cervical Instability
resources.summary: In this follow-up review to a previous literature review on chronic neck pain treatment modalities, the authors reference their previous findings that many treatment modalities, while effective short-term, were not effective long-term for healing. Then the authors provide an overview of chronic neck pain as it relates to cervical instability, assert that instability is a large factor in chronic neck pain, describe the anatomical features of the cervical spine and the impact of capsular ligament laxity, discuss the disorders causing chronic neck pain and their current treatments, and lastly, present prolotherapy as a viable treatment option for instability that heals injured ligaments, restores stability to the spine, and resolves chronic neck pain.

resources.title: Syndrome of occipitoatlantoaxial hypermobility, cranial settling, and Chiari malformation Type I in patients with hereditary disorders of connective tissue
resources.summary:
270 non-randomized patients with a diagnosis of Fibromayalgia and no previous diagnosis of neurological issues were given a neurological assessment for cervical myelopathy and then given imaging. 46% of patients showed cervical stenosis of 10 mm or less.

Study authors recommended further neurological evaluation of patients with Fibromayalgia for neurological issues.

resources.title: COVID-19, Mast Cells, Cytokine Storm, Psychological Stress, and Neuroinflammation
resources.summary:
The authors describe the pathology of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), the infection that causes Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), and conclude that COVID-19 can induce mast cell activation, psychological stress, cytokine storm, and neuroinflammation.

In addition to the economic stress and grief it causes (resulting in emotional distress), COVID-19 can cause severe pneumonia, and neurological disorders, including stroke, the damage to the neurovascular unit, blood-brain barrier disruption, high intracranial proinflammatory cytokines, and endothelial cell damage in the brain. Mast cells are innate immune cells and also implicated in adaptive immune response, systemic inflammatory diseases, neuroinflammatory diseases, traumatic brain injury and stroke, and stress disorders. SARS-CoV-2 can activate monocytes/macrophages, dendritic cells, T cells, mast cells, neutrophils, and induce cytokine storm in the lung. COVID-19 can activate mast cells, neurons, glial cells, and endothelial cells. SARS-CoV-2 infection can cause psychological stress and neuroinflammation. 

The authors describe the various mechanisms involved in each of these pathologies and cite other research.

resources.title: Thinking beyond pannus: a review of retro-odontoid pseudotumor due to rheumatoid and non-rheumatoid etiologies
resources.summary:
Although pseudotumor may have suggestive features on imaging, there are no established criteria to diagnose retro- odontoid pseudotumor, and imaging manifestations can range from thickening of the retro-odontoid soft tissues to mass-like proliferative changes.

In the absence of frankly evident cord compression, the neurological implications of retro-odontoid pseudotumor cannot be reliably judged by supine static MR imaging, as neural compression may be brought on by insta- bility from postural changes 

Although retro-odontoid pseudotumor has been shown to be related to mechanical instability, previous studies have not shown a single specific cause for soft tissue proliferation, and it is difficult to predict which patients will develop pseudotumor.

resources.title: Imaging of the Craniovertebral Junction
resources.summary:
Detailed explanations of  measurements- Chamberlain line, McGregor line, McRae line, Wackenheim line, Welcher basal angle.

Discussion of a fairly comprehensive list of disorders around the CCJ, including basilar invagination, retroodontoid pseudotumor.

resources.title: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension: 12 cases treated by venous sinus stenting
resources.summary:
12 patients with refractory IIH had dilatation and stenting of the venous sinuses.

Symptoms resolved for 5, improved for 2, and were unchanged for 5.

Venography and manometry had shown intracranial venous hypertension proximal to stenoses in the lateral sinuses.

resources.title: Cranio-cervical Instability in Patients with Hypermobility Connective Disorders
resources.summary:
An explanatory paper written by Dr. Henderson that discusses the pros and cons of dynamic imaging and argues in favor of it.

In addition to/support of this argument, the paper generally reviews how CCI is known in CTD's like RA and Down's, but is not as well known in EDS and similar hypermobility CTD's. He explains the Cervical Medullary Syndrome (pathological CCI), the pros and cons of dynamic imaging, the various neurological measurements for assessing upper cervical instability, and also touches on complex Chiari patients.

resources.title: Chiari Malformation Type I: A Case-Control Association Study of 58 Developmental Genes
resources.summary:
A more technical article discussing the common genetic variations among a cohort of roughly 500 patients with Chiari (>3 mm) and 500 controls. 

The study authors identified several genes, primarily the genes involves in the development of paraxial mesoderm (cells in early development that develop along with the neural tube and give rise to the heart, the vertebra, etc.), that may play a role in the development and the extent of Chiari malformation.

resources.title: Use of prone position magnetic resonance imaging for detecting the terminal filum in patients with occult tethered cord syndrome
resources.summary:
Since the pathophysiology of occult tethered cord syndrome (OTCS) has no anatomical evidence of a caudally shifted conus and a normal terminal filum is hard to understand, the diagnosis of OTCS is often difficult.

In this study of fourteen patients with OTCS (Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome) and 12 control individuals, examined using T2-weighted axial MRI with the patients in a prone position on a flat table, the authors hypothesized that the patients with OTCS would have significant differences in their imaging based on elasticity of the terminal filum. 

The authors' new method of using the prone position for MRI shows that the terminal filum is located significantly posterior and the cauda equina is located anterior in patients with OTCS, suggesting a difference in elasticity between the terminal filum and cauda equina.

resources.title: Proposed Diagnostic Algorithm for Patients with Suspected Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
resources.summary:
MCAS diagnostic criteria:

A) Symptoms present in at least 2 organ systems (e.g. throat swelling and abdominal cramping)

B) Biochemical study (preferrably a 20%+ increase in serum tryptase level from baseline)

C) Positive response to drugs targetting mast cell action

resources.title: Spontaneous Intracranial Hypotension: Atypical Radiologic Appearances, Imaging Mimickers, and Clinical Look-Alikes
resources.summary:
Headache which improves when reclining is the classic symptom of a CSF leak. But many patients also present with "vague neurologic symptoms such as nonpositional daily headache, cranial nerve palsy, gait disturbance, and cognitive dysfunction".

Diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement and “brain sag,” were seen in 83% and 61% of cases in a retrospective study. 

Conditions which appear similar in MRI include Chiari malformation, subdural fluid collections, neurosarcoidosis.

Common misdiagnoses of patients with SIH include: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis, Frontotemporal Dementia, Pituitary Tumor or Apoplexy, Superficial Siderosis.

resources.title: Deformative stress associated with an abnormal clivo-axial angle: A finite element analysis.
resources.summary:
A prospective 2-year study of 5 children with ventral brainstem compression from issues like Chiari Malformation or basilar invagination with the thesis that improvement of the CXA with fusion surgery is associated with clinical improvement.

Since about half of patients who undergo decompression surgery still have clinical issues after recovery, and brainstem deformity is an established cause of cervicomedullary symptoms with fusion surgery causing a clinical improvement, the authors sought to use finite element analysis to further support the thesis that in Chiari patients, a fusion surgery may be necessary to alleviate symptoms. 

Higher disability indexes correlated with higher brainstem stress modeling indexes,

resources.title: Diagnostic Accuracy of Videofluoroscopy for Symptomatic Cervical Spine Injury Following Whiplash Trauma
resources.summary:
This study of 196 subjects (119 injured, 77 uninjured) looked at the accuracy of videoslouroscopic (VF or DMX) examination of the cervical spine for identifying instability in whiplash injury patients with chronic pain.

37 VF measurement combinations were observed, and the injured population was significantly more likely to have abnormal measurements. The authors concluded that (1) intervertebral instability is a _common_ finding in the symptomatic population of patients with chronic neck pain after whiplash trauma; (2) intervertebral instability is an _uncommon_ finding in the uninjured population; (3) the finding of two or more abnormal parameters of intervertebral motion during the videofluoroscopic examination of the cervical spine is a highly accurate diagnostic test for identifying patients with chronic neck pain after whiplash trauma.

The authors also included a discussion of the various measurements and measurement cutoffs used for pathology, and further asserted that common diagnoses for patients with chronic pain after whiplash injuries such as malingering, given the study results, are unfounded.

resources.title:
Evaluation of spinal cord 
compression and hyperintense intramedullary lesions on T2-weighted 
sequences in patients with cervical spondylotic myelopathy using 
flexion-extension MRI protocol
resources.summary: Extension MRI helps to identify significant cervical canal stenosis that is partially or completely absent on neutral and flexion MRI and to determine the exact number of levels to decompress surgically.

resources.title: Use of prone position magnetic resonance imaging for detecting the terminal filum in patients with occult tethered cord syndrome
resources.summary:
The study authors tested the hypothesis that prone MRIs of patients with Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome (OTCS) could show reliably a difference from unaffected patients. 14 patients with OTCS and 12 control individuals were examined using T2-weighted MRIs, in a prone position on a flat table, and on each axial view, various measurements were taken.

The study authors found that the patients with OTCS had their terminal filum located significantly posterior and the cauda equina located anterior, as opposed to the unaffected individuals, suggesting a difference in elasticity between the terminal filum and cauda equina.

resources.title: 4 Reports Compare Dynamic MRI in the UPRIGHT Position With Static MRI in the UPRIGHT Position
resources.summary:
Comparison of static vs dynamic MRI for measuring spondylolistheses (slipping of vertebra) in 1,302 patients.

Across all spine sections, static MRI missed 18.1% of cases where vertebrae were slipping more than 3mm.

Just considering L4-L5, the miss rate of static MRI was 35.1%.

This might mean  patients who would benefit from fusion are not receiving treatment, and other patients are having the wrong sections of spine fused because of missed spondylolistheses elsewhere.

Note- article is produced by the manufacturer of the scanning machines.

resources.title: EDS and Its Fellow Traveler, Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
resources.summary: An introduction of the connection between MCAS and EDS

resources.title: Radiopedia- tight filum terminale syndrome
resources.summary: Tight filum terminale syndrome, or tight filum syndrome, is a subtype of the tethered cord syndrome that is attributed to a thick, short, and/or otherwise inelastic filum terminale rather than other tethering agents.

resources.title: Using Dynamic MRI to Diagnose Neck Pain: The Importance of Positional Cervical Cord Compression (PC3)
resources.summary:
A discussion of the complexity of diagnosis of cervical stenosis from static imaging.

"It has become axiomatic that cervical pain and regional imaging often correlate poorly. Both degenerative disc disease and cervical pain are common among our patients. Yet, many have one apparently without the other. One diagnostic response is to discount the informative value of cervical imaging and rely more on history, symptoms, and physical signs. Another is to consider how to better image this area of complex anatomy, without discounting the primary importance of clinical findings"

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Treatment of the Occult Tethered Spinal Cord for Neuropathic Bladder: Results of Sectioning the Filum Terminale
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
Study of 36 patients with severe urinary and/or fecal dysfunction, but with no indication of tethered cord on imaging.

After sectioning of filum terminale, incontinence was resolved in 42% of patients. Urodynamics improved in 72%, bowel symptoms improved in 88%.

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Neurological and spinal manifestations of the Ehlers–Danlos syndromes
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
Connective tissue disorders cause downstream issues including:

- Migraine
- Idiopathic intracranial hypo/hypertension
- Chiari malformation
- Atlantoaxial instability
- Craniocervical instability
- Tethered cord syndrome

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Meningocele Manqué Discovered During Filum Terminale Resection in Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
Case study of a patient with negative imaging, but symptoms of tethered cord. 

On laminectomy, it was discovered that abnormally-developing meningoceles had physically tethered the spinal cord.

Release of the filum terminale would have been insufficient to address symptoms- the tether was at L2-3.

Checking pre-operative imaging again, 3-dimensional reconstruction of a high-resolution MRI would have identified the problem ahead of surgery.

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Filum Section for Urinary Incontinence in Children with Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome: A Randomized, Controlled Pilot Study
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
A study of 21 patients who were selected for sectioning of filum terminale based on urodynamics.

"After 8 years we accrued 21 patients. The bowel and bladder dysfunction score improved in the surgical and medical arms (20% and 24%) and the urodynamic score improved slightly (6% and 4%, respectively). The PEMQOL Child and Family Impact Scales improved modestly in both groups. All differences were nonsignificant. "

The study does not define occult tethered cord syndrome in the way we're used to, concerning itself only with urinary/bowel symptoms:

"OTCS, in which [bladder and bowel dysfunction] is attributed to tethering by the filum despite a normally located conus on MRI."

Whereas OTCS is defined by the NIH as a triad of symptoms: urinary/bowel, neurological, and orthopedic: https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/4018/occult-spinal-dysraphism

This study specifically excludes patients with symptoms in one leg of the triad:

"Evidence of progressive lower extremity motor/ sensory deficits was a patient exclusion criterion."

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Magnetic resonance imaging in the prone position and the diagnosis of tethered spinal cord
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
A small study showing that a comparison of conus position in the spinal canal between prone and supine MRI appears to be a sensitive and specific measure for tethered cord. 

Whereas 38/41 patients with tethered cord had diminished ventral motion, 30/30 controls had > 10% canal width motion.

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Magnetic resonance imaging in the prone position and the diagnosis of tethered spinal cord
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
In this study, with a larger sample size than previous studies, the authors tested the hypothesis that lack of central conus motion (lack of spinal cord movement within the spinal canal) on prone MRI is a sensitive and specific test in identifying patients with occult tethered cord syndrome (OTCS) or a re-tethered cord.

Prone MRI scans from 41 patients who underwent tethered cord release surgery, grouped into 2 groups (new OTCS diagnosis and re-tethered cord) plus a third control group were examined.

Lack of conus motion was found in the OTCS groups, and the sensitivity and specifity of the test (does the test accurately show the problem without false positives?) was found to be above 97%. The authors further suggest 10% canal width motion as a threshold that can separate the tethered and the nontethered groups.

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Disparities in clinical and economic outcomes in children and adolescents following surgery for tethered cord syndrome in the United States
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
In this study, the authors analyzed demographics, complications, and outcomes in children and adolescents who underwent surgery for TCS by retrospectively identifying patients in the national Kids' Inpatient Database (KID).They looked at the rate of surgery complications, surgery outcomes, comorbidities, and more, with kids grouped by age. 

A total of 7397 children and adolescents met the criteria in the 4 studied years. The mean age was 5.7 years; 55.3% of patients were younger than 5 years, 21.5% were 6–10 years, and 16.2% were 11–15 years. Most surgeries were performed in patients who were female (55.0%) and white (64.4%) and were performed at large (49.8%), teaching (94.2%), and urban (99.1%) children's (89.3%) hospitals. The trend showed an increase in prevalence from 2000 (19.9%) to 2009 (29.6%). Common comorbidities included anomalies in spinal curvature (16.7%), urinary or bladder dysfunction (14.3%), and spinal stenosis/spondylosis (1.4%). Non-routine discharges (3.3%) were significantly higher with advancing age, increasing from 2.2% in those younger than 5 years to 9.0% in those older than 15 years (p < 0.0001). There was a similar increasing trend for complications (6.8% to 13.9%, respectively, p < 0.0001) and average LOS (3.5 to 5.1 days, respectively, p < 0.0001). Hospital charges increased with age from an average of $28,521 in those younger than 5 years to $36,855 in those older than 15 years (p < 0.0001).

Older children tended to have more issues with surgery, supporting the conclusion that surgery is better done earlier in life.
###

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Association of Chiari malformation type I and tethered cord syndrome:preliminary results of sectioning filum terminale
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
In this retrosepctive study, the authors examined the scans of a cohort of 2,987 patients with Chiari Malformation Type I (CM-1) and 289 patients with low-lying cerebellar tonsils (LLCT), in addition to findings in 74 children and 244 adults undergoing section of the filum (SFT) (tethered cord release surgery), to determine whether there was a relationship between tethered cord and CM-1.

The authors found that there is a subset of patients who have CM-1 paired with tethered cord syndrome (TCS), different from "generic" CM-1. These patients have distinctive clinical differences: a normal foramen magnum size and the absence of a small posterior cranial fossa, as seen in "generic" CM-1. Other clinical signs that can be seen include elongation and downward displacement of the hindbrain (cerebellar tonsils), normal position of the conus medullaris, a tight filum terminale, and reduced CSF flow in the lumbar theca. 

The authors also discuss preliminary evidence that SFT can reverse moderate degrees of tonsillar ectopia and is appropriate treatment for cerebellar ptosis after Chiari surgery in this cohort.

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Use of prone position magnetic resonance imaging for detecting the terminal filum in patients with occult tethered cord syndrome
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
Since the pathophysiology of occult tethered cord syndrome (OTCS) has no anatomical evidence of a caudally shifted conus and a normal terminal filum is hard to understand, the diagnosis of OTCS is often difficult.

In this study of fourteen patients with OTCS (Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome) and 12 control individuals, examined using T2-weighted axial MRI with the patients in a prone position on a flat table, the authors hypothesized that the patients with OTCS would have significant differences in their imaging based on elasticity of the terminal filum. 

The authors' new method of using the prone position for MRI shows that the terminal filum is located significantly posterior and the cauda equina is located anterior in patients with OTCS, suggesting a difference in elasticity between the terminal filum and cauda equina.

recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.title: Use of prone position magnetic resonance imaging for detecting the terminal filum in patients with occult tethered cord syndrome
recpnQhwTjvEVNCS5.summary:
The study authors tested the hypothesis that prone MRIs of patients with Occult Tethered Cord Syndrome (OTCS) could show reliably a difference from unaffected patients. 14 patients with OTCS and 12 control individuals were examined using T2-weighted MRIs, in a prone position on a flat table, and on each axial view, various measurements were taken.

The study authors found that the patients with OTCS had their terminal filum located significantly posterior and the cauda equina located anterior, as opposed to the unaffected individuals, suggesting a difference in elasticity between the terminal filum and cauda equina.

recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.title: Clinical evidence for cervical myelopathy due to Chiari malformation and spinal stenosis in a non-randomized group of patients with the diagnosis of fibromyalgia
recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.summary:
270 non-randomized patients with a diagnosis of Fibromayalgia and no previous diagnosis of neurological issues were given a neurological assessment for cervical myelopathy and then given imaging. 46% of patients showed cervical stenosis of 10 mm or less.

Study authors recommended further neurological evaluation of patients with Fibromayalgia for neurological issues.

recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.summary:
Connective tissue disorders cause downstream issues including:

- Migraine

recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.title: A case-control study of cerebellar tonsillar ectopia (Chiari) andhead/neck trauma (whiplash)
recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.summary:
In this case-control study, the authors examined the frequency of cerebellar tonsillar ectopia (CTE) in 1,200 MRIs (half upright, half supine) of patients with neck pain, divided into a population of patients who had had a traumatic whiplash injury (600), and a population who had not (600). 

Notably, CTE was found 2.5-times more often in the upright trauma vs the recumbent trauma group and 4-times more often than in either of the non-trauma groups.  The authors conclude that, while more research is needed since this is the first study of its kind, clinicians may want to evaluate their patients for CTE if they have neck pain, a history of a whiplash injury, and other common signs such as bilateral sensory or motor deficits in the upper extremities.

The authors also discussed other effects of whiplash injuries such as dural leaks (CSF leaks).

recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.summary:
In this retrosepctive study, the authors examined the scans of a cohort of 2,987 patients with Chiari Malformation Type I (CM-1) and 289 patients with low-lying cerebellar tonsils (LLCT), in addition to findings in 74 children and 244 adults undergoing section of the filum (SFT) (tethered cord release surgery), to determine whether there was a relationship between tethered cord and CM-1.

270 non-randomized patients with a diagnosis of Fibromayalgia and no previous diagnosis of neurological issues were given a neurological assessment for cervical myelopathy and then given imaging. 46% of patients showed cervical stenosis of 10 mm or less.

Study authors recommended further neurological evaluation of patients with Fibromayalgia for neurological issues.

recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.title: Chiari Malformation Type I: A Case-Control Association Study of 58 Developmental Genes
recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.summary:
A more technical article discussing the common genetic variations among a cohort of roughly 500 patients with Chiari (>3 mm) and 500 controls. 

The study authors identified several genes, primarily the genes involves in the development of paraxial mesoderm (cells in early development that develop along with the neural tube and give rise to the heart, the vertebra, etc.), that may play a role in the development and the extent of Chiari malformation.

recOk9iWFv8SgKzmZ.title: Chiari Malformation Fact Sheet | National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Cervical medullary syndrome secondary to craniocervical instability and ventral brainstem compression in hereditary hypermobility connective tissue disorders: 5-year follow-up after craniocervical reduction, fusion, and stabilization
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary:
This paper is the first 5-year retrospective study of its kind. It is a case series of 22 patients with hypermobile CTDs and complex Chiari patient's (with both Chiari and CCI, basilar invagination, etc.) surgery outcomes 5 years after fusion surgeries. The results were highly positive with no morbidity, few complications (most of the complications involving bone graft harvesting), and patient satisfaction, with 14/20 subjects greatly improving quality of life and functional capacity.

Henderson also explains the various neurological measurements involved in assessing for CCI (with pictures) and describes his surgical technique (also with diagrams). A helpful diagram and list of the top symptoms experience pre- and post-op by patients is also included.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Signs of Intracranial Hypertension, Hypermobility, and Craniocervical Obstructions in Patients With Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary:
In this retrospective, cross-sectional study, the study authors sought to assess whether hypermobility and neurological/neurosurgical issues could be responsible for at least some explanation of the symptoms of severe Myalgic Encaphalomyelitis (ME) (Canada Consensus Criteria). 

229 patients (190 women and 39 men) were assessed for hypermobility (Beighton Score), intracranial hypertension (quotient of the optic nerve sheet diameter (ONSD)/eyeball transverse diameter on both sides), cerebellar tonsil position (McRae's line), craniocervical obstructions, allodynia (quantitative sensory testing (QST)).

The study found a significantly higher percentage of patients in the severe ME population than the general population, with fully half or more of the patients exhibiting these pathologies.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Neurological and spinal manifestations of the Ehlers–Danlos syndromes
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary:
Connective tissue disorders cause downstream issues including:

- Migraine
- Idiopathic intracranial hypo/hypertension
- Chiari malformation
- Atlantoaxial instability
- Craniocervical instability
- Tethered cord syndrome

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Nontraumatic Atlanto-occipital and Atlantoaxial Rotatory Subluxation: Case Report
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary: Interesting case study of a 13 year-old girl who developed CCI/AAI following a neck infection.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Utility of the clivo-axial angle in assessing brainstem deformity: pilot study and literature review
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary:
This article is a literature review paired with a prospective pilot study of ten patients with ventral brainstorm deformity/compression (a kyphotic, or acute, CXA [Clivo-Axial Angle]). Correction of abnormal CXA with fusion and occipito-cervical stabilization correlated with statistically significant clinical improvement in this cohort of patients.

This study's results supported the thesis that a connection between the cervical medullary syndrome and a patient's generally disability with their CXA and assert that a reduction and fusion operation would help alleviate symptoms, after establishing that brainstem deformity has been established to cause neurological deficits.

A description of the diagnostic process, the cervicomedullary syndrome, the effects of brainstem deformity on axons and more, and the surgical procedure with diagrams is also included. This article's literature review includes a wide swath of other studies similar in nature.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Laryngeal Manifestations of Cranial Nerve IX/X Compression at the Brainstem
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary: A study focusing on laryngeal symptoms involving 49 patients with lower cranial nerve vascular compression (LCN IX/X [9 and 10]), where 24 underwent decompression surgery (retromastoid craniectomy) and 25 had conservative treatments. 10/24 surgery patients had complete or near-complete resolution of laryngeal symptoms as opposed to 2/25 conservative management patients. With 4/24 patients having major perioperative complications, the surgery is deemed to have acceptable risk.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: The Classic: The Cervical Syndrome.
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary:
This article is a re-print of Ruth Jackson's 1949 article describing the Cervical Syndrome, a grouping of symptoms gathered by Jackson, associated with cervical nerve root irritation and broken up into vertebra levels. 

Vertebral design and function is described, as well as nerve roots and their larger system and what the nerves control at each level. Causes of nerve root irritation are also listed, chief among them subluxation or instability. Symptoms are described, as is their nature of being made worse with certain neck movements or positions. Treatment protocols are outlined for various issues causing nerve root irritation, such as bracing or injections. 

Jackson asserted the importance of cervical investigation in any patient with head, neck, chest, shoulder and arm pain, and said the usual diagnosis of neuritis, bursitis, periarthritis, myositis, fibrositis, myofascitis, pseudo-angina pectoris and migraine should not be made until cervical nerve root irritation has been ruled out entirely.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Chronic Neck Pain: Making the Connection Between Capsular Ligament Laxity and Cervical Instability
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary: In this follow-up review to a previous literature review on chronic neck pain treatment modalities, the authors reference their previous findings that many treatment modalities, while effective short-term, were not effective long-term for healing. Then the authors provide an overview of chronic neck pain as it relates to cervical instability, assert that instability is a large factor in chronic neck pain, describe the anatomical features of the cervical spine and the impact of capsular ligament laxity, discuss the disorders causing chronic neck pain and their current treatments, and lastly, present prolotherapy as a viable treatment option for instability that heals injured ligaments, restores stability to the spine, and resolves chronic neck pain.

270 non-randomized patients with a diagnosis of Fibromayalgia and no previous diagnosis of neurological issues were given a neurological assessment for cervical myelopathy and then given imaging. 46% of patients showed cervical stenosis of 10 mm or less.

recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.title: Cranio-cervical Instability in Patients with Hypermobility Connective Disorders
recuGBZ7iEvxw9Sle.summary:
An explanatory paper written by Dr. Henderson that discusses the pros and cons of dynamic imaging and argues in favor of it.

In addition to/support of this argument, the paper generally reviews how CCI is known in CTD's like RA and Down's, but is not as well known in EDS and similar hypermobility CTD's. He explains the Cervical Medullary Syndrome (pathological CCI), the pros and cons of dynamic imaging, the various neurological measurements for assessing upper cervical instability, and also touches on complex Chiari patients.

recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.summary:
This article describes Atlanto-Axial Instability (AAI), or hypermobility of the C1-2 segment:

- Its diagnosis (with CT, DMX/X-ray, and MRI)
- The symptoms it causes
- Criteria for surgery
- The patient populations it commonly appears in. 

The author emphasizes that non-traumatic AAI often requires dynamic imaging for proper diagnosis and treatment.

recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.title: Atlanto-axial rotary instability (Fielding type 1): characteristic clinical and radiological findings, and treatment outcomes following alignment, fusion, and stabilization
recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.summary:
Great info on rotary AAI, why it is failed to be diagnosed, and why surgery is harder in CTD patients.

Discusses "occult"  hypermobility- where artifacts are not not visible on traditional scans.

"The alar ligament consists chiefly of inelastic collagen fibers, and can be irreversibly stretched after trauma, potentially leading to chronic occult hypermobility of the cranio-cervical junction.“

recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.title: Syndrome of occipitoatlantoaxial hypermobility, cranial settling, and Chiari malformation Type I in patients with hereditary disorders of connective tissue
recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.summary:
270 non-randomized patients with a diagnosis of Fibromayalgia and no previous diagnosis of neurological issues were given a neurological assessment for cervical myelopathy and then given imaging. 46% of patients showed cervical stenosis of 10 mm or less.

Study authors recommended further neurological evaluation of patients with Fibromayalgia for neurological issues.

recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.title: Thinking beyond pannus: a review of retro-odontoid pseudotumor due to rheumatoid and non-rheumatoid etiologies
recrlprhvu6Bfcw2T.summary:
Although pseudotumor may have suggestive features on imaging, there are no established criteria to diagnose retro- odontoid pseudotumor, and imaging manifestations can range from thickening of the retro-odontoid soft tissues to mass-like proliferative changes.

In the absence of frankly evident cord compression, the neurological implications of retro-odontoid pseudotumor cannot be reliably judged by supine static MR imaging, as neural compression may be brought on by insta- bility from postural changes 

Although retro-odontoid pseudotumor has been shown to be related to mechanical instability, previous studies have not shown a single specific cause for soft tissue proliferation, and it is difficult to predict which patients will develop pseudotumor.

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: Signs of Intracranial Hypertension, Hypermobility, and Craniocervical Obstructions in Patients With Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary:
In this retrospective, cross-sectional study, the study authors sought to assess whether hypermobility and neurological/neurosurgical issues could be responsible for at least some explanation of the symptoms of severe Myalgic Encaphalomyelitis (ME) (Canada Consensus Criteria). 

229 patients (190 women and 39 men) were assessed for hypermobility (Beighton Score), intracranial hypertension (quotient of the optic nerve sheet diameter (ONSD)/eyeball transverse diameter on both sides), cerebellar tonsil position (McRae's line), craniocervical obstructions, allodynia (quantitative sensory testing (QST)).

The study found a significantly higher percentage of patients in the severe ME population than the general population, with fully half or more of the patients exhibiting these pathologies.

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: Neurological and spinal manifestations of the Ehlers–Danlos syndromes
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary:
Connective tissue disorders cause downstream issues including:

- Migraine
- Idiopathic intracranial hypo/hypertension
- Chiari malformation
- Atlantoaxial instability
- Craniocervical instability
- Tethered cord syndrome

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: Venous sinus stenting for refractory benign intracranial hypertension
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary: This article is a case study of a woman with refractory intracranial hypertension, who upon venography and manometry (venous imaging) was found to have partial obstruction of both transverse venous sinuses, with raised pressures proximal to the obstructions. The patient improved significantly, including her intracranial hypertension, after insertion of a stent to reduce the pressure gradient. This case study-- along with other literature supporting a relationship between intracranial pressure and venous obstruction-- indicates that venous issues should be investigated in the setting of an intracranial hypertension diagnosis.

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: Ultrasonographic measurement of the optic nerve sheath diameter and its association with eyeball transverse diameter in 585 healthy volunteers
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary:
In the evaluation of intracranial pressure (ICP) for the diagnosis of various disorders such as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, optic nerve sheath diameter (ONSD) is often used as an indirect marker of ICP. The authors of this study sought to clarify the unclear optimal cut-off of ONSD and the general use of ONSD in evaluating ICP.

Using ultrasonography (a non-invasive method for measuring ONSD) on 585 healthy volunteers, the authors measured ONSD, and found that of the factors studied, only eyeball transverse diameter (ETD) was independently associated with ONSD. The authors established a normative (normal) value for ONSD and ETD, and a normative value for the ONSD/ETD ratio, and further asserted that the ONSD/ETD ratio might be a more reliable marker for ICP than ONSD alone.

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: The link between idiopathic intracranial hypertension, fibromyalgia, and chronic fatigue syndrome: exploration of a shared pathophysiology
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary:
This article is a literature review exploring the idea that since fibromayalgia (FM) and chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) aren't well understood and their symptoms have significant overlap with idiopathic intracranial hypertention (IICH or IIH), the symptoms of FM and CFS could be caused by increased intracranial and spinal fluid pressure.

Literature reviewed discussed common symptoms for all 3 conditions and their overlap, the mechanism for nerve involvement in IICH, common symptoms associated with each nerve's involvement, the high incidence of small fiber neuropathy (SFN) in these patients, the involvement of the sympathetic nervous system, disability and quality of life among these patients, and the role of cerebral blood flow in all 3 conditions.

The authors concluded that IICH, FM, and CFS share very similar characteristics and probably are caused by the same underlying disorder, and that IICH, FM, and CFS can be considered progressive neurological disorders affecting the central and peripheral nervous systems. They point out the stigma associated with FM and CFS diagnoses and urge further investigation into treating intracranial and spinal fluid pressure.

They further assert that this hypothesis may also provide an explanation for several overlapping chronic pain conditions, including FM, CFS, temporomandibular disorders, irritable bowel syndrome, chronic tension headache, chronic migraine, severe dry eyes, and chronic nonspecific low back pain.

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension: 12 cases treated by venous sinus stenting
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary:
12 patients with refractory IIH had dilatation and stenting of the venous sinuses.

Symptoms resolved for 5, improved for 2, and were unchanged for 5.

Venography and manometry had shown intracranial venous hypertension proximal to stenoses in the lateral sinuses.

recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.title: Spontaneous Intracranial Hypotension: Atypical Radiologic Appearances, Imaging Mimickers, and Clinical Look-Alikes
recQ7F8nVA6ZePDU1.summary:
Headache which improves when reclining is the classic symptom of a CSF leak. But many patients also present with "vague neurologic symptoms such as nonpositional daily headache, cranial nerve palsy, gait disturbance, and cognitive dysfunction".

Diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement and “brain sag,” were seen in 83% and 61% of cases in a retrospective study. 

Conditions which appear similar in MRI include Chiari malformation, subdural fluid collections, neurosarcoidosis.

Common misdiagnoses of patients with SIH include: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis, Frontotemporal Dementia, Pituitary Tumor or Apoplexy, Superficial Siderosis.

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Autoantibodies to beta-adrenergic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors in Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME) patients – A validation study in plasma and cerebrospinal fluid from two Swedish cohorts
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:
If you have these antibodies, the acetylcholine receptors on your cells may be damaged, meaning you need, in essence, more acetylcholine than usual to function properly. 

Mestinon blocks acetylcholinesterase, an enzyme that breaks down acetylcholine, thereby increasing acetylcholine. 

Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter of the vagus nerve. It also regulates mast cell degranulation, and so may pay a role in MCAS.

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Altered Structural Brain Networks Related to Adrenergic/Muscarinic Receptor Autoantibodies in Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome: A Primer for the Gastroenterologist
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary: "Gastroenterologists who become aware of this syndrome can dramatically improve the quality of life for their patients who previously have been labeled with a functional gastrointestinal disorder."

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Characterization of Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:
413 patients, selected both retrospectively and prospectively.

Abnormalities in routine labs were common and diverse but typically modest. The most useful diagnostic markers were heparin, prostaglandin D2, histamine, and chromogranin A. Flow cytometric and cytokine assessments were unhelpful.

Treatment of samples is crucial: "Also, other work has clarified the importance of continuous specimen chilling, including use of refrigerated centrifugation for plasma separation, when seeking plasma heparin levels."

The discussion section has some interesting speculation about whether some diagnoses found as comorbidities may in fact be unrecognised MCAS- for example GERD, thrombocytopenia purpura, polycythemia vera, etc.

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Effect of acetylcholine on mast cells of the dura mater
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:
In this study using rats, the authors tested the effect of various doses of acetylcholine (100, 200, and 500 mg/kg) on the mast cells of the albino rat dura mater (sheath around the spinal cord).

The authors found that acetylcholine has an activating effect on monoamine secretion, using measured differences in the accumulated or eliminated monoamines after dosing.

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Proposed Diagnostic Algorithm for Patients with Suspected Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:
MCAS diagnostic criteria:

A) Symptoms present in at least 2 organ systems (e.g. throat swelling and abdominal cramping)

B) Biochemical study (preferrably a 20%+ increase in serum tryptase level from baseline)

C) Positive response to drugs targetting mast cell action

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: EDS and Its Fellow Traveler, Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary: An introduction of the connection between MCAS and EDS

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: MCAS- Compatibility of foodstuffs
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary: Compatibility list for diagnostic and therapeutic elimination diet at histaminosis (mast cell activity syndrome MCAS, mastocytosis, histamine intolerance), compiled from various sources and based on experience reports

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome handout
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary: MCAS primer and MCAS multi-step treatment approach

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Medication for mast cell activation diseases
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:
Therapeutic strategy for MCAD

Active ingredients of medications, medical products, food supplements and foods for special medical purposes: Mechanisms of action, application, advantages and disadvantages

Recommendations for use in basic therapy, symptomatic adjunctive therapy and in special situations (premedication before medical interventions and dental treatments, allergies, ana- phylactic shock, infections, vaccinations, pregnancy and lactation, mental illnesses)

Guidance for the assessment of compatibility of products

With references to the scientific literature

reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.title: Living With Mast Cell Activation Syndrome- EHLERS-DANLOS SOCIETY GLOBAL LEARNING CONFERENCE
reckOoCIhEZYdoNw4.summary:
Mast Cells are in every organ of the body. 

Provides context around the neurological manifestations beyond the diet, hives, and benadryl MCAS stereotype.

rec3nvKSDcLVXuFo0.title: Cerebral Blood Flow Is Reduced in ME/CFS During Head-Up Tilt Testing Even in the Absence of Hypotension or Tachycardia: A Quantitative, Controlled Study Using Doppler Echography
rec3nvKSDcLVXuFo0.summary: Doppler flow imaging was used to measure cerebral blood flow (CBF) in 429 ME/CFS patients and 44 healthy controls during a head-up tilt test. CBF was reduced 26% in ME/CFS patients vs. 7% in controls. CBF reduction was > 2 standard deviations in 90% of ME/CFS patients vs 13% of controls.

recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.title: Improvement of severe ME/CFS symptoms following surgical treatment of cervical spinal stenosis
recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.summary:
Case study of 3 moderate/severe ME/CFS patients who were diagnosed with cervical stenosis following a cervical MRI. 
Measures of neurological function improved significantly after treatment.

recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.title: Incidence of Extrinsic Compression of the Internal Jugular Vein in Unselected Patients Undergoing CT Angiography
recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.summary:
Study of 108 consecutive patients already having a (supine) CT angiogram for reasons other than vascular issues (so although these are not healthy controls, there's no strong reason to believe their symptoms are because of stenosis).

Interestingly, 67.6% of people had some narrowing of one or other jugular.

Collateral veins can form around the main veins when flow is blocked. But the study shows a complex picture where although collateral veins are far more common in people with stenosis of the main vein, they can also be present without; and severe stenosis can exist without the formation of collateral vessels.

As with so many  comorbidities we've found in our cohort of people with ME, identification of pathologies requires specialist knowledge,  sophisticated reading of imagery, and many signs can be incidental in patients without symptoms.

recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.title:
Evaluation of spinal cord 
compression and hyperintense intramedullary lesions on T2-weighted 
sequences in patients with cervical spondylotic myelopathy using 
flexion-extension MRI protocol
recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.summary: Extension MRI helps to identify significant cervical canal stenosis that is partially or completely absent on neutral and flexion MRI and to determine the exact number of levels to decompress surgically.

recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.title: Using Dynamic MRI to Diagnose Neck Pain: The Importance of Positional Cervical Cord Compression (PC3)
recIEXw3MH6BAtcA7.summary:
A discussion of the complexity of diagnosis of cervical stenosis from static imaging.

"It has become axiomatic that cervical pain and regional imaging often correlate poorly. Both degenerative disc disease and cervical pain are common among our patients. Yet, many have one apparently without the other. One diagnostic response is to discount the informative value of cervical imaging and rely more on history, symptoms, and physical signs. Another is to consider how to better image this area of complex anatomy, without discounting the primary importance of clinical findings"
